name: Dokkie
slogan: Split the bill, not your friend group.
intro: Not many things are as deeply rooted into Dutch culture as sharing the bill. Many people nowadays use apps to help this process, to keep track of all expenses, and to accurately calculate what everyone has to pay. Dokkie does exactly that. It was my first academic project.

body.alt: Some of the core pages when logged in, viewed on a phone

body.content: Dokkie allows you to create events, and invite other users to them. You can then add costs to an event, and lock the event to finish. All users will then get access to a shareable list of transactions that must be made. Locking the event also starts payment tracking, offering an easy way to keep track of who you've sent money too, who you still need to pay and who you should still receive money from.

body.alt: The home page when logged in, viewed on desktop

body.content: The project follows the Google Material Design 3 guidelines, using their colors according to the guidelines and implementing some of their components.

body.alt: Part of the landing page

name: BandiThemepark
slogan: The next generation of Minecraft themeparks.
intro: Back in february 2020 I got invited to join a project called BandiThemepark. BandiThemepark is a fictional themepark, built in a modified version of the famous videogame Minecraft. It's a project where we push Minecraft to its limits, and try to innovate and push the community forwards.

body.alt: The home page of our store

body.content: I work as a developer on the project. I mainly develop the Minecraft part, done in Kotlin, but also do some designing and web development, like with our store.

body.alt: The shopping cart sheet that appears before checkout
Further details on the product page of our 'VIP-rank'. All renders and art are by me as well

body.content: BandiThemepark exists out of a lot of different services. This includes our main game-server, a website, a webstore & internal administration and management tools. Almost all of these run using Docker, and are powered by CI/CD. We also have communication between most of our services, some via a (partially public) REST API, and some using MQTT.

body.alt: The landing page of our main site, www.bandithemepark.net

body.content: Our main website is powered by a content management system (CMS) called Strapi, so that anyone in our team can easily edit and update the site. It is also Search Engine Optimized.

body.alt: The login page of our administration tool
The screen to manage so-called achievements players can get by exploring the themepark

body.content: These are some of the web-apps I have worked on for BandiThemepark. I was also involved in developing the main REST API that powers most of our services, but my main task was the game-server(s) code. Most of that is hard to show, especially if you are not familiar with Minecraft. I do have some visualization for the rollercoasters I programmed though.

body.alt: Our in-game rollercoaster editor, which visualizes the spline of the ride

body.content: This picture shows our rollercoaster system. Minecraft does not have (realistic) rollercoasters as part of the base-game, so I was responsible for programming them. At their core, these rollercoasters are Bezier splines, that have trains that follow these. These trains have physics and collisions, and their rendering is powered by matrices and quaternions. Each rollercoaster also has a realistic control system, modeled after real-life examples.

name: Code Exchange
slogan: Empowering students to help each other.
intro: My second academic project was a coding forum for students, inspired by StackOverflow.

name: TripSwift
slogan: Quickly view Dutch public transport data.
intro: One day, I started getting annoyed with the 9292 app I was using to get my bus times. 9292 only shows your saved bus stops on the departure times screen, after your location has been loaded. This can makes it so that you often have to wait at least a few seconds. It also doesn't have a quick button to see departure times of a saved stop on the home page either.

body.alt: These are the main screens of the app. Bus 305 is the one I take from Central Station to get back home!

body.content: At one point I got so annoyed, that I decided to create my own app. It's simple, but extremely quick to use. I still use it every single day. The app was made with Jetpack Compose and Kotlin, and uses Google's Material Design 3. It also uses the dynamic color system introduced in Android 12. This way, it always matches the look and feel of my phone's UI.

name: Elections
slogan: Accessible insight into election data for everyone.
intro: My academic project for my third semester was a site to view Dutch election results. One of the major parts of this project was working with big amounts of data (up to 3GB per election). Much work was put into optimizing code and multi-threading. A lot of focus was also put into making viewing this data as easy as possible.

body.alt: The core page showing a summary of the selected election's results
The main page to go deep into the data
The admin dashboard, with some simple statistics and a tool to load election data
The party information page, showcasing some general information, and more detailed information about their result per municipality
A map that offers an easier way to interpret election results of a party
